Homewood, Baltimore, December 19, 1952

Vol. LV11—No. 11

Bennett's Anti-Fraternity
Ordinance 'Pigeon -holed'
By RONNIE STAHL
The Legislative Committee of the Baltimore City Council, meeting
• this past Tuesday, pigeon-holed the ordinance proposed by Howard
P. Bennett of 2833 St. Paul St., -which was directed at Hopkins
fraternities.
Richard Cohn, who represented the fraternities at the hearing,
stated the reasons given by the Committee for the pigeon-holing were
that three points in the proposed ordinance were already on the books,

Those points which were questioned from a legal standpoint by
two of the councilmen were those which give police officers permission
to hold the officers of a fraternity responsible for the actions of its
members, and that part of the ordinance which made a first or second
offense punishable by a mandatory fine of $50 and a third offense

P.O. Boxes Robbed, public."
Legal Advice Sought
Students Report
Various lawyers contacted
Several students have reported
the unlawful removal of mail from
their post office boxes, Gene Zemsky, Student Counicl President,
said this week.
Material has been stolen from
the open boxes which are reserved
for in-town students and from
closed boxes which have damaged
locks or broken windows.
Harry Magee, Hopkins Postmaster, stated that the condition has
existed "for ages."
Zemsky stated that it is a
federal offense to tamper with
U.S. Mail.
"Such practices are also a direct
violation of the Honor Code. Any
student who sees someone stealing
Is obligated to report it to the
Zemsky
Commission,"
Honor
added.

the fraternities in conjunction
with the proposed ordinance expressed the feeling that the two
councilmen were correct in questioning the legality of certain
points in the ordinance. They said
that the points in question were
definitely "unconstitutional," and
if passed and brought to court
would be declared as such.
During his calls to the Vigilance
Committee Bennett was invited to
appear at IFB meetings om Dec. 5
and 12. He agreed to come in
order to try to iron out the problems, but on each occasion he
failed to appear.
At the hearing Bennett admitted
that whenever he called the Vigilance Committee in reference to a
complaint, he had received satisfaction, but he said that he didn't

proudly presents authentic

MASTER OF SCIENCE
And

DOCTOR OF SCIENCE DEGREES
PURPOSE

To assist outstanding BS graduates in
obtaining their Master of Science and
Doctor of Science Degrees while employed in industry and making a significant contribution to national defense
work.
ELIGIBILITY

January and June 1953 graduates receiving BS Degrees in the following fields:
Aeronautical Engineering
Civil Engineering
Electrical, Engineering
Electronic Engineering
Mechanical Engineering
Physics
Those chosen to participate in this Plan
will be from the upper portion of their
graduating class and will have evidenced
unusual technical ability. They must
also have evidenced imaginative ability
and possess personality traits enabling
them to work well with others.
CITIZENSHIP

"DIXIELAND AT THE SUMMIT"

Applicants must be United States citizens who can be cleared for "Secret."
PARTICIPATING UNIVERSITY

on Pimlico Road—South of Falls Road. North of Smith Avenue

EVERY SUNDAY 3 P. M. TO 7 P. M.
featuring

RUSS DISNEY AND HIS NEW ORLEANS DIXIELANDERS
Preacher. Ambrose, Sashmo, Samba. Jezebel, Canal Street Morgan and
Trombone Willie plus Banjo Music Direct from the Cotton Fields

NO MINORS

$1.00

FOR RESERVATIONS

COVER CHARGE
"Where The Elite Meet"

TUxedo 9733

Washington University in St. Louis will
participate in this program and candidates for Master of Science and Doctor
of Science Degrees must meet entrance
requirements for advanced students at
this university.
PROGRAM

Under this Graduate Plan the candidate
will work full time at McDonnell Aircraft Corporation until September 1953.
Friw September 1953 to June 1954
candidates will work at M.A.C. from 28

to 36 hours per week, attending Washington University on an.individually arranged schedule. A Master of Science
Degree should be obtained within a
maximum of two,calendar years. Under
this arrangement it will be possible for
a candidate to earn approximately 85%
of a normal year's salary and to attend
the university during regular semesters
while working toward his advanced degree.
COMPENSATION

Compensation will be commensurate
with the individual's ability and experience. Compensation growth will be on
the same basis as the full time members
of the engineering staff. In addition, the
candidate will be eligible for all other
benefits accruing to full time employees.
TUITION

Tuition covering the required number of
units necessary to obtain an advanced
degree will be paid .by McDonnell Aircraft Corporation.
SELECTION OF CANDIDATES

Candidates will be selected by officials
of McDonnell Aircraft Corporation and
Washington University.
DATES FOR APPLYING

January 1953 graduates should make informal applications prior to January 10,
1953. McDonnell Aircraft Corporation
will then forward formal applications
which should be returned by January 20,
1953, accompanied by up to date grade
transcripts. Selections will be made during the month of February. June 1953
graduates should make ,informal appheation no later than March 15, 1953.

ADDRESS CORRESPONDENCE TO
Technical Placement Supervisor
McDonnell Aircraft Corporation
Post Office Box 516
St. Louis 3, Missouri

Homewood, Baltimore, December 19, 1952

Vol. LV11—No. 11

Bennett's Anti-Fraternity
Ordinance 'Pigeon -holed'
By RONNIE STAHL
The Legislative Committee of the Baltimore City Council, meeting
• this past Tuesday, pigeon-holed the ordinance proposed by Howard
P. Bennett of 2833 St. Paul St., -which was directed at Hopkins
fraternities.
Richard Cohn, who represented the fraternities at the hearing,
stated the reasons given by the Committee for the pigeon-holing were
that three points in the proposed ordinance were already on the books,

Legal Advice Sought
Students Report
Various lawyers contacted
Several students have reported
the unlawful removal of mail from
their post office boxes, Gene Zemsky, Student Counicl President,
said this week.
Material has been stolen from
the open boxes which are reserved
for in-town students and from
closed boxes which have damaged
locks or broken windows.
Harry Magee, Hopkins Postmaster, stated that the condition has
existed "for ages."
Zemsky stated that it is a
federal offense to tamper with
U.S. Mail.
"Such practices are also a direct
violation of the Honor Code. Any
student who sees someone stealing
Is obligated to report it to the
Zemsky
Commission,"

points in the ordinance. They said
that the points in question were
definitely "unconstitutional," and
if passed and brought to court
would be declared as such.

proudly presents authentic

MASTER OF SCIENCE
And

DOCTOR OF SCIENCE DEGREES
PURPOSE

To assist outstanding BS graduates in
obtaining their Master of Science and
Doctor of Science Degrees while employed in industry and making a significant contribution to national defense
work.
ELIGIBILITY

January and June 1953 graduates receiving BS Degrees in the following fields:
Aeronautical Engineering
Civil Engineering
Electrical, Engineering
Electronic Engineering
Mechanical Engineering
Physics
Those chosen to participate in this Plan
will be from the upper portion of their
graduating class and will have evidenced
unusual technical ability. They must
also have evidenced imaginative ability
and possess personality traits enabling
them to work well with others.
CITIZENSHIP

"DIXIELAND AT THE SUMMIT"

Applicants must be United States citizens who can be cleared for "Secret."
PARTICIPATING UNIVERSITY

on Pimlico Road—South of Falls Road. North of Smith Avenue

EVERY SUNDAY 3 P. M. TO 7 P. M.
featuring

RUSS DISNEY AND HIS NEW ORLEANS DIXIELANDERS
Preacher. Ambrose, Sashmo, Samba. Jezebel, Canal Street Morgan and
Trombone Willie plus Banjo Music Direct from the Cotton Fields

NO MINORS

$1.00

FOR RESERVATIONS

COVER CHARGE
"Where The Elite Meet"

TUxedo 9733

Washington University in St. Louis will
participate in this program and candidates for Master of Science and Doctor
of Science Degrees must meet entrance
requirements for advanced students at
this university.
PROGRAM

Under this Graduate Plan the candidate
will work full time at McDonnell Aircraft Corporation until September 1953.
Friw September 1953 to June 1954
candidates will work at M.A.C. from 28

to 36 hours per week, attending Washington University on an.individually arranged schedule. A Master of Science
Degree should be obtained within a
maximum of two,calendar years. Under
this arrangement it will be possible for
a candidate to earn approximately 85%
of a normal year's salary and to attend
the university during regular semesters
while working toward his advanced degree.
COMPENSATION

Compensation will be commensurate
with the individual's ability and experience. Compensation growth will be on
the same basis as the full time members
of the engineering staff. In addition, the
candidate will be eligible for all other
benefits accruing to full time employees.
TUITION

Tuition covering the required number of
units necessary to obtain an advanced
degree will be paid .by McDonnell Aircraft Corporation.
SELECTION OF CANDIDATES

Candidates will be selected by officials
of McDonnell Aircraft Corporation and
Washington University.
DATES FOR APPLYING

January 1953 graduates should make informal applications prior to January 10,
1953. McDonnell Aircraft Corporation
will then forward formal applications
which should be returned by January 20,
1953, accompanied by up to date grade
transcripts. Selections will be made during the month of February. June 1953
graduates should make ,informal appheation no later than March 15, 1953.

ADDRESS CORRESPONDENCE TO
Technical Placement Supervisor
McDonnell Aircraft Corporation
Post Office Box 516
St. Louis 3, Missouri
